topic.title: Installing HP Helion OpenStack Using the UI

body.section: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 Beta 2 comes with a UI for installing your cloud. Rather than searching through and editing a number of YAML files to input your specific configuration data, finding the correct location, and maintaing the format of the files, the UI presents fields in which you may enter your information.

In addition, rather than having to run a series of commands to execute the cobbler and ansible scripts that initiate the installation of HP Helion OpenStack, the UI application runs them behind the scenes.

While the UI app does more than simply popoulate the configuration files that the configuration processor uses as input to its processses, it does populate them. Therefore you can inspect the files whenever you like, or before reconfiguing your cloud.
These YAML configuration files are now stored in a local git repository as well, as explained in Using git for Configuration Manangement.

Before you begin Before you run the GUI installer to install your cloud, there are a number of things you need to do to prepare.
Prepare your servers
Gather your information
Server names
IP addresses
Server Roles
PXE MAC addresses
PXE IP addresses
PXE interfaces
IPMI/iLO IP address, username, password
Choose your cloud model/example template
Install HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack based on your hypervisor by following the appropriate installation instructions:
KVM
ESX
You will follow the installation instructions found on the installation page, stopping before the step "Run the Configuration Processor" and skipping the "Configure Your Environment" steps. Therefore, your last OS install step will be ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml

Running the GUI to install your cloud
The UI is found on the deployer node at: http://<Deployer_IP>:79/dayzero
You should SSH tunnel in with the username/password set up when installing the deployer. Username and password should be what was set in "Set up the Deployer" in the installation instructions. For example: ssh -v -N -L 8080:<Deployer_IP>:79 <Username>@<Deployer_IP>
Then on your local machine, point your web browser to: http://localhost:8080/dayzero As you proceed through the GUI, you need only supply your server names and IP addresses.
Contextual help is provided throughout.
When the installation is complete, the Ansible log will be displayed on the final page.
The GUI is used only once: during the initial installation of your cloud.
To understand a cloud configuration more thoroughly and to learn how to make any changes later, visit these documentation pages:
HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 Input Model
Using Git for Configuration Management
